feed.title: Stories by Mohit Poudel on Medium
feed.description: Stories by Mohit Poudel on Medium

items.title: Comparing genetic sequences of threatening bat-borne viruses
items.author: Mohit Poudel
items.description:
DAY5/7

Today, in this article we are performing a comparative analysis of nucleotide sequences obtained from sequencing of Hendra Virus and Nipah Virus.

This is a part of a self-learning challenge performed by me, a student of plant science, in Nepal. All the information used is extracted from the internet and used for the sake of learning purposes only.

Both Hendra and Nipah viruses can cause fatal diseases in humans, horses, pigs, and other mammals, and are transmitted between humans and animals. The flying fox, a bat species, is considered the viruses’ natural host. The very similar pathogens, discovered in the 1990s in Australia and Malaysia, respectively, cause severe respiratory symptoms and brain inflammation that lead to death in up to 95% of those infected.

Read more from: https://news.osu.edu/good-news-on-blocking-a-virus-considered-a-global-threat/

A notebook file of Sequence analysis done using Jupyter Notebook is shared below:

https://medium.com/media/7dc3a28a122050c518715688f1332b4a/href

Finally, this article is prepared by a newbie who has not taken any training or course on bioinformatics or even programming. As this blog is published just out of curiosity to learn bioinformatics without proper guidance, the material is susceptible to any degree of error. As you have reached the end of the article, please consider providing feedback to the writer.

items.title: Beginner’s guide to Phylogenetic Tree construction using BioPython
items.author: Mohit Poudel
items.description:
DAY4/7

This is a part of a self-learning challenge performed by (me)Mohit Poudel, a student of biology, in Nepal. All the information used is extracted from the internet and used for the sake of learning purposes only.

An Intro to Phylogenetic Tree

Phylogenetics is the study of the evolutionary history and relationships among or within groups of organisms. To demonstrate the relation, some sort of graphics are used. As in the picture above, phylogenetic tree is a branching diagram showing the relation between different species (as leaf in branch of tree ) arranged according to the similarities on genetic characters.

The length of the branch (if present) corresponds to the time taken for evolution while each node with descendants represents the most recent common ancestor of the descendants. Each node is called a taxonomical unit.

Different methods are present for the construction of Phylogenetic Trees, such as:

  1. Parsimony
  2. Distance Matrix Based
  3. Maximum Likelihood

Out of these three, today we are exploring phylogenetic trees based on Distance Matrix. Distance Matrix methods use ‘genetic distance’ between the sequences to be analyzed so we need Multiple Sequence Alignment (MSA) as input. In case you are unfamiliar with MSA, please go through this article on medium.

Distance is measured as the fraction of mismatches at aligned positions and the matrix is constructed based on the distance by placing closely related sequences under the same interior node.

Commonly used file formats for the phylogenetic tree:

  1. Nexus
  2. Newick

Different software are available for Phylogenetic Tree construction and analysis such as ClustalW, Dendroscope, FastTree 2, PHYLIP, etc. Today, we will be using BioPython which is a set of freely available tools for biological computation written in Python by an international team of developers.

Steps we are following today:

  1. Extraction of sequences
  2. Multiple Sequence Alignment
  3. Coding for Phylogenetic Tree Construction

1. Extraction of Sequences:

ACE2 helps modulate the many activities of a protein called angiotensin II (ANG II) that increases blood pressure and inflammation, increasing damage to blood vessel and many more. When the SARS-CoV-2 virus binds to ACE2, it prevents ACE2 from performing its normal function to regulate ANG II signaling. Learn more from here: https://theconversation.com/what-is-the-ace2-receptor-how-is-it-connected-to-coronavirus-and-why-might-it-be-key-to-treating-covid-19-the-experts-explain-136928

ACE2 protein sequence of human was extracted from UniProt dataset and BLAST was run from the same site. https://www.uniprot.org/uniprotkb/Q9BYF1/entry

Out of the total results received, 12 sequences were randomly selected for the study purpose.

Fasta files of the selected sequences were then downloaded and read using BioPython.

https://medium.com/media/bf4411d925523c6760ea202ec0937919/href

2. Multiple Sequence Alignment

For Multiple Sequence Alignment, Combined Fasta File (combined_sequence.fasta) was uploaded on Web Based Tool MUSCLE and the aligned file was downloaded on the working directory as ‘align.clw’

3. Tree Construction

https://medium.com/media/076a1c1986ab6c56c29be552c78dd83e/href

Image of Tree using UPGMA Model:

UPGMA is the simplest method for constructing trees. The great disadvantage of UPGMA is that it assumes the same evolutionary speed on all lineages, i.e. the rate of mutations is constant over time and for all lineages in the tree.

Image of Tree using Neighbour-Joining Model:

Finally, this article is prepared by a newbie who has not taken any training or course on bioinformatics or even programming. As this blog is published just out of curiosity to learn bioinformatics without proper guidance, the material is susceptible to any degree of error. As you have reached the end of the article, please consider providing feedback to the writer.

References:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distance_matrices_in_phylogeny
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phylogenetic_tree
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nexus_file
https://theconversation.com/what-is-the-ace2-receptor-how-is-it-connected-to-coronavirus-and-why-might-it-be-key-to-treating-covid-19-the-experts-explain-136928
https://medium.com/media/9c170e257c514f23ebfa6a731c1cabf4/href

Thank You !!!

https://medium.com/media/076a1c1986ab6c56c29be552c78dd83e/href

Image of Tree using Neighbour-Joining Model:

As this blog is published just out of curiosity to learn bioinformatics without proper guidance, the material is susceptible to any degree of error. As you have reached the end of the article, please consider providing feedback to the writer.

References:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distance_matrices_in_phylogeny
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phylogenetic_tree
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nexus_file
https://theconversation.com/what-is-the-ace2-receptor-how-is-it-connected-to-coronavirus-and-why-might-it-be-key-to-treating-covid-19-the-experts-explain-136928
https://medium.com/media/9c170e257c514f23ebfa6a731c1cabf4/href

Thank You !!!

items.title: Multiple Sequence Alignment and Jalview
items.author: Mohit Poudel
items.description:
DAY3/7

This is a part of a self-learning challenge performed by (me)Mohit Poudel, a student of biology, in Nepal. All the information used is extracted from the internet and used for the sake of learning purposes only.

According to Wikipedia, sequence alignment is a way of arranging the sequences of DNA, RNA, or protein to identify regions of similarity that may be a consequence of functional, structural, or evolutionary relationships between the sequences. For instance, Sequence alignment of protein gives an overview of how unchanged the particular region of protein is during the evolutionary process.

Multiple sequence alignment (MSA) may refer to the process of sequence alignment of three or more biological sequences which are mostly, assumed to have shared evolutionary relationships.
Multiple sequence alignments can be used to visualize conserved sequences in order to infer sequence homology or to perform phylogenetic analysis.

Out of different file formats, the Clustal format is used mostly for sequence alignment tasks. The CLUSTAL format includes a plain-text key to annotate conserved columns of the alignment, denoting conserved sequence (*), conservative mutations (:), semi-conservative mutations (.), and non-conservative mutations ( )

Different softwares have been developed for multiple sequence alignment purposes, such as SAM, Opal, MUSCLE, etc.

Today, we are going to use MUSCLE for multiple-sequence alignment

MUltiple Sequence Comparison by Log-Expectation (MUSCLE) is computer software for multiple sequence alignment of protein and nucleotide sequences.

To download and install MUSCLE, please refer to this youtube video from Bioinformatics Coach :

https://medium.com/media/162a40d0913a984c84ec7d06e6017ebc/href

In order to perform multiple sequence alignment, we actually need sequences to align. Following a youtube tutorial from Simon Cockell, I have obtained 12 sequences of protein from the Uniprot database https://www.uniprot.org/

Bash Script has been created to extract those sequences and perform multiple sequence alignments using MUSCLE once installed.

Uniprot ids of the sequence to be extracted are saved in a text file named uniprots_id.txt, which can be downloaded from my GitHub repository as well.
In case, you are not familiar with GitHub, you can copy the ids and save them as uniprots_id.txt on your local machine.

Ids:
Q9BYF1
G3QWX4
Q5RFN1
F7AH40
A0A5F4W5D9
Q56H28
Q5EGZ1
Q8R0I0
F6WXR7
G1KTF3
E7F9E5
A0A1L8HCX9

Bash Script:¶

https://medium.com/media/320cebfd38c59f8af927addd87851ab2/href

Alternatively, sequence alignment of combined files can also be done online with web-based service via: https://www.ebi.ac.uk/Tools/msa/muscle/

Exploring aligned Sequence with Jalview

Sequences can be aligned in Jalview itself, using a range of algorithms provided by JABA web services, including ClustalW1, Muscle2, MAFFT3, ProbCons,4 T-COFFEE5, and Clustal Omega.6 .Of these, MUSCLE is fast and probably best for smaller alignments

Here, we have used the output of our bash script as input to jalview for some exploration of Jalview software. To input the file:

step1: conda activate env (where env is the environment in which jalview was installed)

step2: open the software by typing ‘jalview’ on your terminal step3: go to file -> Input alignment -> from file

Now we have successfully added the aligned file in jalview.

Coloring

Different options related to coloring can be accessed through the ‘color’ menu out of which some are explained below:

Percentage Identity

The Percentage Identity option colors the residues according to the percentage of the residues in each column that agree with the consensus sequence. Only the residues that agree with the consensus residue for each column are colored.

Zappo

The residues are colored according to their physicochemical properties. The physicochemical groupings are Aliphatic/hydrophobic, Aromatic, Positive, Negative, Hydrophilic, Conformationally special, and Cyst(e)ine

Nucleotide

Residues are colored with four colors corresponding to the four nucleotide bases. All non-ACTG residues are uncolored.

Phylogenetic tree construction

Jalview can calculate and display trees, providing interactive tree-based grouping of sequences through a tree viewer. All trees are calculated via the Calculate ⇒ Tree or PCA . . . menu option.

We will be learning more about phylogenetic trees probably in upcoming blogs !!

PCA

Principal components analysis is a technique for examining the structure of complex data sets. The components are a set of dimensions formed from the measured values in the data set, and the principal component is the one with the greatest magnitude or length. The sets of measurements that differ the most should lie at either end of this principal axis, and the other axes correspond to less extreme patterns of variation in the data set

PCA plots can be constructed from Jalview through Calculate -> Tree or PCA option after selecting the sequences. The PCA plots are found to be of below-average quality.

Finally, this blog post is prepared by a newbie who has not taken any training or course on bioinformatics or even programming. As this blog is published just out of curiosity to learn bioinformatics without proper guidance, the material is susceptible to any degree of error. As you have reached the end of the blog, please spare a few minutes to provide feedback to the writer.

items.title: GC-count in python
items.author: Mohit Poudel
items.description:
DAY2/7

Today, I have explored about ‘GC content’ and created a function to determine the GC content of a given sequence using Python.

https://medium.com/media/9847730703fcb72629c9eef584adcd4d/href

items.title: File Formats in Bioinformatics
items.author: Mohit Poudel
items.description:
DAY 1/7

Today I have explored some standard file formats commonly used in bioinformatics-related tasks. The objective is to be friendly with all those huge files that are to be handled not only while following different sequences analyzing youtube tutorials but also when we will be working on bioinformatics labs in the future.

  1. FASTA

.fasta is a text-based format to represent either nucleotide or peptide sequences.Extension like ‘.fasta’ , ‘.fa’ , ’.fna’(for nucleic acids), .faa(for amino acids) are also used.

The name FASTA derives from a software package written in the mid-1980s that searches quickly through large collections of sequence data — the software is called FASTA but is also called FAST-N (nucleotide) and FAST-P (protein). This format was designed by David Lipman and William Pearson from the University of Virginia.

The FASTA file header consists of “>” at the beginning often starting with a unique accession number and followed by optional information like the name of the gene, the type of sequence, and the organism it is from. Below the header is the sequence starting in the second line.

A multiple-sequence FASTA format can be obtained by concatenating several single-sequence FASTA files in a common file (also known as multi-FASTA format).

example of a fasta format:

>BTBSCRYR
tgcaccaaacatgtctaaagctggaaccaaaattactttctttgaagacaaaaactttca
aggccgccactatgacagcgattgcgactgtgcagatttccacatgtacctgagccgctg
caactccatcagagtggaaggaggcacctgggctgtgtatgaaaggcccaattttgctgg
gtacatgtacatcctaccccggggcgagtatcctgagtaccagcactggatgggcctcaa
cgaccgcctcagctcctgcagggctgttcacctgtctagtggaggccagtataagcttca
gatctttgagaaaggggattttaatggtcagatgcatgagaccacggaagactgcccttc
catcatggagcagttccacatgcgggaggtccactcctgtaaggtgctggagggcgcctg
gatcttctatgagctgcccaactaccgaggcaggcagtacctgctggacaagaaggagta
ccggaagcccgtcgactggggtgcagcttccccagctgtccagtctttccgccgcattgt
ggagtgatgatacagatgcggccaaacgctggctggccttgtcatccaaataagcattat
aaataaaacaattggcatgc

2. FASTQ

Fastq file format is similar to the Fasta format with an additional quality score. Line 1 begins with “@” followed by the sequence identifier and optional description. Line 2 is raw sequence letters while Line 3 begins with the “+” character optionally followed by the same sequence identifier and descriptions. Line 4 are quality scores (PHRED Score) for sequence in Line 2. This format was developed by the Sanger institute.

Higher the Phred score, greater the probability that base was sequenced and identified properly. A Phred Score of 20 indicates the likelihood of finding 1 incorrect base call among 100 bases.ASCII character codes (33–126) are used in place of numeric values to denote the Phred scores in Line 4 of fastq files.

example of a fastq file :

@SRR12132977.1 1/1
AACAAACCAACCAACTTTCGATCTCTTGTAGATCTGTTCTCTAAACGAACAAACTAAAATGTCTGATAATGGACCCCAAAATCAGCGAAATGCACCCCGCATTACGTTTGGTGGACCCTCAG
+
C@CCD>DBC?B692;;;09?<BBBBC>BBBBBBBBB@?ABB@BC<BBB>@A?:999992;=>>@??==:=C;>=<:'555)8;;;;;AG:AAAAADD;CCBB>?@;;;0:<@A>CEE?CFCC
@SRR12132977.2 2/1
AACAAACCAACCAACTTTCGATCTCTTGTAGATCTGTTCTCTAAACGAACTTTAAAATCTGTGTGGCTGTCACTCGGCTGCATGCTTAGTGCACTCACGCAGTATAATTAATAACTAATTACTGTCGTTGACAGGACACGAGTAACTCGTCTATCTTCTGCAGGCTGCTTACGGTTTCGTCCGTGTTGCAGCCGATCATCAGCAC
+
A>A@@=@@F@D@C<999,:<@ABBBB@B=>=BB@BBB?@@><;;7>??=BBB>BDD;D>????@@;@CDC@@@BBB>BBB@AAC>>9BBBB;;;@@?;><::;99<9<;A;>><@@A:=:>@@@>A@>:>===>:=<<>>;;;>=BCAA?>=A>>>:==>;998<=;===@@@<>>9>>>?;??==:=>>>>:>>;;;;;;;<;;

3. SAM

SAM stands for Sequence Alignment Map . It was developed by Heng Li and Bob Handsaker et al. The SAM format consists of a header and an alignment section. SAM files can be analysed and edited with the software SAMtools.

The header section must be prior to the alignment section if it is present. Headings begin with the ‘@’ symbol, which distinguishes them from the alignment section. Below header, Alignment sections are present with 11 mandatory fields, as well as a variable number of optional fields.

Mandatory fields and their meaning are:

QNAME : Query name where * means not available

FLAG : combination of bit-wise flags to denote multiple attributes of read sequence

RNAME : Name of reference sequence generally chromosome number

POS : 1-based leftmost mapping POSition of the first matching base

MAPQ : Mapping Quality where 255 means ‘not available’

CIGAR : Strings to describe alignment

RNEXT : Reference name of next read

PNEXT : position of next read

TLEN : Observed template length

SEQ : Segment Sequence

QUAL : ASCII of Phreds-scale based quality plus 33

See more about SAM file formats from here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SAM_(file_format)

4. BAM

BAM standing for Binary Alignment Map, is compressed binary version of a SAM file that is used to represent aligned sequences.

BAM files contain a header section and an alignment section:

▶Header — Contains information about the entire file, such as sample name, sample length, and alignment method. Alignments in the alignments section are associated with specific information in the header section.
▶Alignments — Contains read name, read sequence, read quality, alignment information, and custom tags. The read name includes the chromosome, start coordinate, alignment quality, and the match descriptor string.

5. VCF

VCF is the standard file format for storing variation data. It is used by large scale variant mapping projects such as IGSR. It is also the standard output of variant calling software such as GATK and the standard input for variant analysis tools such as the VEP or for variation archives like EVA.

VCF is a preferred format because it is unambiguous, scalable and flexible, allowing extra information to be added to the info field. Many millions of variants can be stored in a single VCF file.

There are some other file formats such as .gff, .gff2, .gvf, .maf, .tsv and many more.

In Day2 of the 7 days series, we will be exploring another concept( of which I have no idea yet). Let the journey begin...

DAY 1/7

Today I have explored some standard file formats commonly used in bioinformatics-related tasks. The objective is to be friendly with all those huge files that are to be handled not only while following different sequences analyzing youtube tutorials but also when we will be working on bioinformatics labs in the future.

>BTBSCRYR

2. FASTQ

Fastq file format is similar to the Fasta format with an additional quality score. Line 1 begins with “@” followed by the sequence identifier and optional description. Line 2 is raw sequence letters while Line 3 begins with the “+” character optionally followed by the same sequence identifier and descriptions. Line 4 are quality scores (PHRED Score) for sequence in Line 2. This format was developed by the Sanger institute.

Higher the Phred score, greater the probability that base was sequenced and identified properly. A Phred Score of 20 indicates the likelihood of finding 1 incorrect base call among 100 bases.ASCII character codes (33–126) are used in place of numeric values to denote the Phred scores in Line 4 of fastq files.

example of a fastq file :

@SRR12132977.1 1/1
AACAAACCAACCAACTTTCGATCTCTTGTAGATCTGTTCTCTAAACGAACAAACTAAAATGTCTGATAATGGACCCCAAAATCAGCGAAATGCACCCCGCATTACGTTTGGTGGACCCTCAG
+

@SRR12132977.2 2/1
AACAAACCAACCAACTTTCGATCTCTTGTAGATCTGTTCTCTAAACGAACTTTAAAATCTGTGTGGCTGTCACTCGGCTGCATGCTTAGTGCACTCACGCAGTATAATTAATAACTAATTACTGTCGTTGACAGGACACGAGTAACTCGTCTATCTTCTGCAGGCTGCTTACGGTTTCGTCCGTGTTGCAGCCGATCATCAGCAC
+
A>A@@=@@F@D@C<999,:<@ABBBB@B=>=BB@BBB?@@><;;7>??=BBB>BDD;D>????@@;@CDC@@@BBB>BBB@AAC>>9BBBB;;;@@?;><::;99<9<;A;>><@@A:=:>@@@>A@>:>===>:=<<>>;;;>=BCAA?>=A>>>:==>;998<=;===@@@<>>9>>>?;??==:=>>>>:>>;;;;;;;<;;

3. SAM

SAM stands for Sequence Alignment Map . It was developed by Heng Li and Bob Handsaker et al. The SAM format consists of a header and an alignment section. SAM files can be analysed and edited with the software SAMtools.

The header section must be prior to the alignment section if it is present. Headings begin with the ‘@’ symbol, which distinguishes them from the alignment section. Below header, Alignment sections are present with 11 mandatory fields, as well as a variable number of optional fields.

Mandatory fields and their meaning are:

QNAME : Query name where * means not available

FLAG : combination of bit-wise flags to denote multiple attributes of read sequence

RNAME : Name of reference sequence generally chromosome number

POS : 1-based leftmost mapping POSition of the first matching base

MAPQ : Mapping Quality where 255 means ‘not available’

CIGAR : Strings to describe alignment

RNEXT : Reference name of next read

PNEXT : position of next read

TLEN : Observed template length

SEQ : Segment Sequence

QUAL : ASCII of Phreds-scale based quality plus 33

See more about SAM file formats from here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SAM_(file_format)

4. BAM

BAM standing for Binary Alignment Map, is compressed binary version of a SAM file that is used to represent aligned sequences.

BAM files contain a header section and an alignment section:

▶Header — Contains information about the entire file, such as sample name, sample length, and alignment method. Alignments in the alignments section are associated with specific information in the header section.
▶Alignments — Contains read name, read sequence, read quality, alignment information, and custom tags. The read name includes the chromosome, start coordinate, alignment quality, and the match descriptor string.

5. VCF

VCF is the standard file format for storing variation data. It is used by large scale variant mapping projects such as IGSR. It is also the standard output of variant calling software such as GATK and the standard input for variant analysis tools such as the VEP or for variation archives like EVA.

VCF is a preferred format because it is unambiguous, scalable and flexible, allowing extra information to be added to the info field. Many millions of variants can be stored in a single VCF file.

There are some other file formats such as .gff, .gff2, .gvf, .maf, .tsv and many more.

In Day2 of the 7 days series, we will be exploring another concept( of which I have no idea yet). Let the journey begin...
